p: Needless to say, our recommendations fell upon deaf ears. Only 3 issues later, we were warning about the consequences of growing trends in science denialism, “alternative facts,” isolationism, and politicization (Apitz, Backhaus et al. 2017). Although these were not new issues, in the United States or internationally, the ferocity of their increase was alarming. We (and others) called upon scientists and others to make their work understandable, to engage with the public and decision makers, and to expose scientific fraud and respond to alternative facts in a way that was understandable and acceptable to the general public, or face dire, global consequences.
